questions.text: Match the following surgical procedures used in the management of CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equino Varus) with their correct description:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  1. Posteromedial Soft Tissue Release (PMSTR)

Indication:

  • Resistant or relapsed CTEV in children aged 6 months to 3 years, especially when non-operative treatment (Ponseti) fails.

Procedure:

  • Release of tight soft tissues including:
    • Posterior structures: Tendoachilles, posterior ankle capsule, tibialis posterior
    • Medial structures: Deltoid ligament, spring ligament
    • Plantar fascia
    • Sometimes flexor hallucis longus and flexor digitorum longus
  • Goal: Achieve correction of equinus, varus, and cavus deformities.

Post-op:

  • Immobilization in cast for ~6 weeks followed by bracing.
  1. Percutaneous Achilles Tenotomy

Indication:

  • Equinus deformity persisting after 4-5 serial Ponseti casts in infants (<6 months).

Procedure:

  • Outpatient, percutaneous division of tendoachilles under local anesthesia.
  • Performed with a small scalpel blade (#15) or tenotomy knife.
  • Foot is immediately dorsiflexed after cut, and a final cast is applied for 3 weeks.

Purpose:

  • Allows full dorsiflexion by eliminating posterior tension.

Outcome:

  • Tendon regenerates within weeks; this is a key part of Ponseti method success (used in >90% cases).
  1. Triple Arthrodesis

Indication:

  • Neglected or recurrent CTEV in older children/adolescents (>10 years).
  • Severe rigid deformity where soft tissue release alone is insufficient.

Procedure:

  • Fusion of three joints:
    • Subtalar joint
    • Talonavicular joint
    • Calcaneocuboid joint
  • May be combined with bony wedge resections.
  • Goal: Create a plantigrade, stable, painless foot-not necessarily full mobility.

Drawbacks:

  • Permanent loss of hindfoot motion.
  • Risk of arthritis in adjacent joints over time.
  1. Dwyer's Osteotomy

Indication:

  • Residual hindfoot varus deformity in rigid CTEV (esp. in older children).

Procedure:

  • Lateral closing wedge osteotomy of the calcaneus.
  • Wedge of bone is removed from the lateral side, allowing the heel to shift into a neutral or valgus position.

Goal:

  • Correct varus alignment of the hindfoot, especially when soft tissue release is insufficient or failed.

questions.text: All are causes of clubfoot at birth except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Poliomyelitis cause acquired club foot deformity. It is not seen at birth. Whereas club foot due to other causes mentioned here can be seen at birth.

  • Poliomyelitis cause acquired club foot deformity. It is not seen at birth.
  • Club foot can be primary or secondary
  • Primary
    • Idiopathic (MC)
  • Secondary
    • Neurological disorders
      • Spina bifida
      • Meningomyelocele
      • Myelodysplasia
      • Poliomyelitis
    • Syndromes
      • Arthrogryposis Multiplex Congenita
      • Larsen's syndrome

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to the orthopedic outpatient clinic with complaints of limited neck movements noticed since early childhood. Radiographs reveal congenital fusion of cervical vertebrae. The pediatrician suspects Klippel-Feil syndrome. Which of the following findings, if present, would not be considered part of the classic triad of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Elevated scapula is a feature of Sprengel shoulder and is not a part of Klippel Feil syndrome.
  • Klippel Feil syndrome is a congenital condition characterized by abnormal fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae, leading to a short, immobile neck and other skeletal and systemic anomalies.
  • Klippel Feil syndrome is a Triad of
    • Short neck
    • Low hair line
    • Restricted neck movement(Option A,B and C ruled out)
  • It occurs due to the failure of segmentation of the cervical vertebra resulting in the formation of a block vertebra which is immobile and short.

questions.text: Sprengel shoulder can be associated with all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sprengel shoulder is congenital Undescended scapula, due to failure of descent during embryonic development.
  • Its associations are -
    • Klippel Feil syndrome (33%)
    • Congenital Scoliosis
    • Disastemetomyelia
    • Renal disease

Definition

  • Sprengel deformity is a congenital elevation of the scapula.
  • It occurs due to the failure of the scapula to descend from the cervical to thoracic region during fetal development.
  • The scapula remains high-riding and malrotated on the back.

Embryology

  • During normal development, the scapula migrates from C4-C5 level to T2-T7 level between the 5th and 12th weeks of gestation.
  • Arrest or incomplete migration leads to Sprengel deformity.

Clinical Features

  1. Elevated scapula (visible shoulder asymmetry)
  2. Medial rotation of scapula (inferior angle points toward spine)
  3. Limited shoulder abduction (usually <90°)
  4. Muscle hypoplasia- underdevelopment of trapezius, rhomboids, and levator scapulae
  5. Often cosmetically obvious and noticed in early childhood

Omovertebral Bone

  • Present in 20-50% of cases.
  • It is an abnormal bony or fibrous connection between the scapula (usually its superior angle) and cervical spine (commonly C5 or C6).
  • It limits scapular mobility further.

Radiological Features

  • Elevated, medially rotated scapula
  • Omovertebral bone (if present)
  • Look for associated cervical spine abnormalities on X-ray or CT

Treatment

  1. Observation- for mild, asymptomatic cases
  2. Surgical correction - indicated for:
    • Functional limitation (especially abduction restriction)
    • Cosmetic deformity (especially Grade III or IV)
    • Ideally performed between 3-5 years of age
  3. Common surgeries include:
    • Woodward procedure
    • Green's procedure

choices.text: Can be associated with a mass

questions.text: Not true about congenital muscular torticollis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Congenital muscular torticollis occurs because of the contracture of sternocleidomastoid muscle and there is no fusion of vertebrae. Fusion of vertebrae is seen in Klippel Feil syndrome.
  • Sometimes a mass can be palpable in the SCM which is the fibrotic muscle.

Etiology:

  • The exact cause is uncertain but commonly believed to result from intrauterine malpositioning, birth trauma, or ischemia leading to fibrosis of the SCM.
  • It may be associated with sternomastoid tumor, a palpable mass within the muscle appearing in infancy.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Usually noticed between 2 to 4 weeks of age.
  • The infant holds the head tilted to the affected side with limited neck motion.
  • The classic "cock robin" posture is seen: head tilted ipsilaterally and chin rotated contralaterally.(Option C ruled out)
  • Palpation may reveal a firm, non-tender mass in the lower part of the SCM muscle (sternomastoid tumor).( Option B ruled out)
  • Passive neck motion is limited, especially in rotation and lateral bending.

Associated Findings:

  • May be associated with positional plagiocephaly (flattening of the head on one side).
  • Increased incidence of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) reported in some cases.

Diagnosis:

  • Primarily clinical based on history and examination.
  • Ultrasound may confirm SCM thickening and help differentiate from other neck masses.

Treatment:

  • Most cases respond well to conservative treatment, especially with early diagnosis.
  • Treatment includes passive stretching exercises, physical therapy, and parental education.
  • Splinting or orthotic devices rarely needed.
  • Surgery is reserved for persistent cases after 1 year of age or with significant deformity, often involving release or lengthening of the SCM.

choices.text: Vicker's ligament can be a cause
Prominent ulna with a short bowed radius

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Madelung deformity is Defect in distal radius physis. It continues to worsen till skeletal maturity and then becomes non progressive.
  • It is a deformity of distal forearm where the distal radius is shortened with ulno-volar curvature and the distal ulna is lengthened.( Option A ruled out)
  • This occurs due to the disruption of the ulnar volar physis of the distal radius.
  • This causes asymmetric growth, leading to a shortened and bowed radius.ulna becomes relatively prominent( Option C ruled out)
  • It is idiopathic, but may be associated with an abnormal ligament called the Vicker's ligament.( Option B ruled out)
  • Vicker's ligament is an abnormal fibrous band extending from the distal radius to the lunate bone.
  • It tethers the growth plate and contributes to growth arrest and deformity.

Common Causes of Madelung deformity:

  1. Idiopathic (Primary) - often bilateral and more common in females
  2. Genetic syndromes:
    • Léri-Weill dyschondrosteosis (SHOX gene mutation)
    • Turner syndrome
    • Multiple hereditary exostoses
  3. Post-traumatic or acquired - due to physeal injury

Radiographic Findings

  • Volar and ulnar tilt of the distal radial articular surface
  • Increased radial inclination
  • Shortened radius
  • Dorsal subluxation of the distal ulna
  • Appearance of a triangular carpus due to carpal malalignment
  • Vicker's ligament may be identified on MRI or during surgery

Explanation:

  • Poland's syndrome is the congenital absence of pectoralis major
  • It is the most common congenital absence of muscle
  • Risk factors - Maternal Diabetes
  • Associations
    • Sprengel's deformity
    • Scoliosis
    • Dextrocardia
    • Absence of the breast
    • Hand deformities
  • More common in males
  • Usually sporadic, though some cases suggest a vascular disruption sequence during embryogenesis

questions.text: In which condition is JESS (Joshi's External Stabilization System) used for?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • JESS (Joshi's External Stabilization System) is used for the correction of neglected CTEV.
  • It is type of external fixation device.

JESS (Joshi's External Stabilization System) is a mini external fixator system designed by Dr. B.B. Joshi, primarily used for:

  • Correcting pediatric orthopedic deformities
  • Gradual distraction and realignment in resistant or complex cases

Primary Indications:

  • Neglected or resistant Congenital Talipes Equino Varus (CTEV)
    Especially when conventional methods like Ponseti casting have failed or in older children.
  • Post-burn contractures (e.g., hand, foot)
  • Deformity correction (angular or rotational)
  • Limb lengthening / Distraction osteogenesis

Explanation of Other Options:

Fracture around knee (Option A) - Typically treated with internal fixation, casting, or conventional external fixators- JESS is not preferred.

Pelvis fracture (Option B) - Managed with pelvic binders, anterior ring fixators, or internal fixation- not JESS.

Poliomyelitis (Option D) - While JESS may be used secondarily to correct post-polio deformities, it is not a treatment for poliomyelitis itself.

choices.text: Inherited as an autosomal dominant trait
Caused by FGFR 3 mutation on Chr 4
The problem is defective enchondral ossification of long bones

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In achondroplasia, the IQ and sexual development are absolutely normal.
  • Achondroplasia
    • MC skeletal dysplasia
    • MC cause of disproportionate dwarfism
    • Autosomal dominant (Option A ruled out)
    • Caused due to FGFR 3 mutation on Chr 4( Option B ruled out)
    • The basic problem is defective enchondral ossification of long bones( Option C ruled out)
    • Proximal bones are most affected - Rhizomelic shortening

Clinical Features:

  • Short limbs with normal-sized trunk
  • Large head with frontal bossing
  • Midface hypoplasia
  • Trident hand (short, stubby fingers with a separation between the middle and ring fingers)
  • Normal intelligence and life expectancy
  • Possible complications: spinal stenosis, recurrent otitis media, apnea

Radiological Features:

  • Short, thickened long bones with metaphyseal flaring
  • Narrow interpedicular distances in the lumbar spine
  • Skull shows large calvarium with small foramen magnum

questions.text: A infant is noted to have a characteristic hand as shown in the image below what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows starfish hand and is seen in achondroplasia

  • Star fish hand is seen in achondroplasia.
  • Achondroplasia is the most common skeletal dysplasia in humans.
  • It is autosomal dominant and caused due to FGFR 3 mutation on Chromosome 4
  • Clinical features are
    • Proximally migrated mid point
    • Saddle nose
    • Frontal bossing
    • Hand
      • Brachydactyly
      • Starfish hand
      • Trident hand
    • Normal IQ and sexual development
  • X ray changes include
    • Bullet nose vertebrae
    • Decreasing inter-pedicular distance from L1 to S1
    • Champagne glass pelvis
    • Inverted V shaped distal femoral physis

Explanation of Other Options:

Down's syndrome (Option A)

  • Genetic disorder caused by trisomy 21.
  • Characteristic features include a single palmar crease, hypotonia, and intellectual disability.
  • No polydactyly or starfish/trident hand is seen.
  • Hand findings are different (simian crease, clinodactyly).

Achondroplasia (Option B)

  • Caused by a mutation in FGFR3 gene.
  • Classic skeletal dysplasia with disproportionate short stature.
  • Hand: Trident hand, not polydactyly.
  • Trident hand means fingers are short and broad, with a widened space between the middle and ring fingers, giving a "Y" or starfish-like shape.
  • This is often confused with the term "starfish hand," but it actually refers to the trident shape of fingers due to the gap.

Patau syndrome (Option C) (Trisomy 13)

  • Presents with true polydactyly (extra fingers), cleft lip/palate, severe intellectual disability, microcephaly.
  • Poor prognosis and multiple systemic anomalies.

Metaphyseal dysplasia (Option D)

  • Skeletal dysplasia affecting metaphyseal regions, causing short limbs and bowing.
  • No characteristic hand deformity like trident or polydactyly.

questions.text: Bullet nose vertebrae is seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Achondroplasia is the most common skeletal dysplasia in humans.
  • It is autosomal dominant and caused due to FGFR 3 mutation on Chromosome 4
  • X ray changes include
    • Bullet nose vertebrae
    • Decreasing inter-pedicular distance from L1 to S1
    • Champagne glass pelvis
    • Inverted V shaped distal femoral physis

choices.text: Break the intact cortex, reduce and cast

questions.text: A 4 year old child is brought with history of fall. X ray shows a crack in the dorsal cortex of shaft of right radius and intact volar cortex. What is the treatment..
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This child has sustained a green stick fracture.
  • Green stick fractures are unicortical fractures seen in children
  • They are treated by making the fracture complete and reducing it and applying plaster. This process of completing a fracture by breaking the intact cortex is called osteoclasis.
  • The intact cortex prevents full realignment, so to achieve proper reduction, the intact cortex is deliberately broken (complete the fracture) to allow correction of angulation, followed by casting.
  • If osteoclasis is not done, there is risk of deformity when the child grows.

Explanation of Other Options:

Reduction and casting (Option A)

  • This means attempting to realign the fracture by manipulation and then applying a cast.
  • In greenstick fractures with intact cortex, this may not always be enough because the intact cortex acts as a hinge and may prevent perfect reduction.
  • Sometimes acceptable if displacement is minimal and stable.

ORIF (Open Reduction and Internal Fixation) (Option B)

  • Usually not required in children for greenstick fractures of the radius unless fracture is severely displaced or unstable.
  • Children's bones remodel well; invasive surgery is avoided if possible.

Splinting (Option C)

  • Simple immobilization without reduction, usually for non-displaced fractures.
  • In this case, since the dorsal cortex is cracked and there may be angulation, splinting alone is often insufficient.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child falls on an outstretched hand during play. X-rays reveal fracture. All are incomplete fractures except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Night stick fracture is an isolated fracture of the ulna and it is seen in adults. It is a complete fracture.
  • Incomplete fractures are usually seen in children. They are
  1. Greenstick fracture: Incomplete fracture common in children, where one side of the cortex breaks (tension side) and the opposite cortex remains intact but bent. It's actually named for resembling a green (young) stick bending and cracking(Option A ruled out)
  2. Torus fracture: Another incomplete fracture, where compressive forces cause bulging/plating of the cortex without a full break-clinically and radiographically incomplete .( Option C ruled out)
  3. Plastic deformation: Especially seen in pediatric bones, where bones bow without any visible fracture. Entire cortex is intact but deformed-qualifies as an incomplete injury, often called a plastic bowing fracture( Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 7 year old child fell from a tree and sustained injury to the right ankle. X-ray taken did not show any fractures and was treated with crepe bandage. At 10 years of age the child presents with valgus deformity of right ankle. What could be the cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This child has sustained a type V physeal injury.
  • In type V injuries there is crushing of a part or whole of the physis.
  • Many a time these injuries will not be visible on the initial x ray.
  • These injuries will get revealed only later when the child grows and deformities develop in the affected bone due to physeal arrest.

Salter-Harris Classification of Physeal (Growth Plate) Injuries

Type I - Slip

  • Fracture passes only through the physis
  • May be hard to detect on X-ray
  • Common in SCFE (slipped capital femoral epiphysis)

Type II- Above

  • Fracture through physis and metaphysis
  • Most common type (~75%)

Type III - Lower

  • Fracture through physis and epiphysis
  • Involves the articular surface → risk of joint dysfunction
  • Requires precise anatomic reduction

Type IV - Through

  • Fracture line crosses metaphysis, physis, and epiphysis
  • Can disrupt growth and joint congruity

Type V - Rammed

  • Compression/crush injury to the growth plate
  • Often missed on X-ray initially
  • Causes physeal growth arrest → angular deformity or limb length discrepancy
  • Worst prognosis

Explanation of Other Options:

SH Type I physeal injury(Option A): A transverse fracture through the physis only, not typically leading to growth disturbance or angular deformity-especially if adequately treated

Malunited distal tibial fracture(Option C) : Would have been visible on initial imaging and treated accordingly, not hidden under crepe bandage.

Physiological valgus(Option D) : Normal tibio-talar valgus in children is mild and symmetrical; it would not be unilateral or progressive following an injury.

questions.text: A 5 year old girl fell from her bed and sustained injury to her right wrist. X-ray shows a fracture line at the distal radius physis with a triangular metaphyseal fragment. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The triangular metaphyseal fragment seen on the x ray is called the Thurston Holland fragment and it is seen in type II physeal injuries.
  • Type II injuries usually have good prognosis.
  • This is the most common physeal injury, especially in the distal radius (~75%)

Explanation of Other Options:

SH Type I (A)

  • Fracture through the physis only, no metaphyseal or epiphyseal involvement.
  • No metaphyseal fragment.
  • Rarely shows a visible fracture line-often diagnosed clinically.
  • Not correct here due to the presence of a metaphyseal fragment.

SH Type III (C)

  • Fracture through the physis and into the epiphysis, hence intra-articular.
  • No metaphyseal fragment present.
  • Usually requires surgical anatomical reduction to preserve joint integrity.
  • Not applicable here.

SH Type IV (D)

  • Fracture extends through metaphysis, physis, and epiphysis,intra-articular.
  • Has both metaphyseal and epiphyseal involvement, but unlike Type II, also disrupts the epiphysis.
  • Would be visible as an articular surface deformity.

questions.text: Match the Salter-Harris fracture types with their respective examples:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • SH Type I (SCFE):
    This involves a fracture through the physis only, causing the epiphysis to slip relative to the metaphysis. SCFE typically occurs in adolescents and is a classic example of a pure physeal injury without metaphyseal or epiphyseal involvement.
  • SH Type II (Distal radius fracture with metaphyseal fragment):
    This is the most common Salter-Harris fracture type. It involves a fracture through the physis and metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis. The characteristic triangular metaphyseal fragment is known as the Thurston-Holland fragment.
  • SH Type III (Tillaux fracture):
    This fracture involves the epiphysis and physis but not the metaphysis. It is an intra-articular fracture seen in adolescents, caused by avulsion of the anterolateral distal tibial epiphysis during partial physeal closure.
  • SH Type IV (Triplane fracture):
    This fracture passes through the metaphysis, physis, and epiphysis, making it a more complex injury. The triplane fracture is characteristic of the distal tibia in adolescents and involves fracture planes in multiple anatomical planes.
  • SH Type V (Growth arrest due to crush injury):
    This is a compressive injury to the physis that may be occult on initial X-rays but causes growth arrest and subsequent deformity, such as valgus or varus angulation of the ankle.
